'}, {'created': '2021-04-27 03:19:30.000000000', 'message': 'Allow unknown attributes in Server resource requests

The min_count and max_count kwargs are listed as valid kwargs on the
ComputeCloudMixin.create_server method but when they are specified,
they are not passed through to the eventual call to the nova REST API
because they are not defined as known/allowed attributes on the Server
class.

This sets _allow_unknown_attrs_in_body = True on the Server class to
allow valid request parameters that are not returned in the response
body (examples: min_count and max_count) to be honored when passed to
the create_server method.

Story: 2008856
Task: 42377

Change-Id: Iaaedd292dc3dcf6486914d3b1f404ad95b12daeb

class.

Story: 2008856

commit_message:
Add min_count and max_count attributes to Server

The min_count and max_count kwargs are listed as valid kwargs on the
ComputeCloudMixin.create_server method but when they are specified,
they are not passed through to the eventual call to the nova REST API
because they are not defined as known/allowed attributes on the Server
class.

This adds min_count and max_count attributes to the Server class so
they will be honored when specified when calling create_server.

Story: 2008856
Task: 42377

Change-Id: Iaaedd292dc3dcf6486914d3b1f404ad95b12daeb

subject: Test SRIOV port move operations with PCI conflicts
messages:
[{'account_id': 8864, 'date': '2021-03-25 19:23:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 8864, 'date': '2021-03-25 19:26:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2021-03-25 19:27:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2021-03-25 19:28:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2021-03-25 19:59:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

-1 since this does not actually replicate the failure.

you need to assert that today the migration will succeed but that the pci_slot is not update in the port bidning profile and that the value does not match the vaule claimed in the db.

to do that you will need create a compute host wtih 2 VFs.
boot a vm and shelve it then boot another vms and assert it gets teh saem pci device as the shelve one then unshleve the vm.

in reality this woudl fail with the libvirt error in the bug in the test fixture i expecct it will succeed but if you check the profil you will see that both vms have the same pci device.

you could also add a spy to the xml generation and you could assert that the unshelved vm is infact using the same deivce in its xml but that is not strectly required once you assert that the data in the port used in each vm refers to the same pci adddress.

in addtion to that you can assert that the seconned vm has actully claimed that vf in pci_device table and that the adress of the device claimed for the first vm does not match the value in the port'}, {'account_id': 8864, 'date': '2021-03-26 16:20:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 8864, 'date': '2021-03-26 16:45:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 8864, 'date': '2021-03-27 15:26:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2021-03-31 23:57:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

(7 comments)

this is a pretty soft -1 mainly i would like you to use uniqe mac and ip adress in the fixture
everythin else is just minor nits.

the test logic looks good to me.
i was debating about resize but the code path we care about is shared between cold migrate and resize so i dont think that would real add value and it would just make the tests longer.'}, {'account_id': 8864, 'date': '2021-04-01 16:23:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

commit_message:
Test SRIOV port move operations with PCI conflicts

This patch tests cold migration, unshelve and evacuate in a situation
where the existing port binding's pci_slot would cause a conflict on
the destination compute node. While cold migration and evacuation
work correctly, in the unshelve case the pci_slot is not updated,
resulting in two instances attempting to consume the same PCI device.
This "passed" in the functional tests, but with a real libvirt this
would obviously explode.

Related: bug 1851545

Change-Id: Ib81532dc1e6dd85822e38eb1785ffb7162d2a84d

Do not include vmedia kernel parameter while building the ISO for
ilo-uefi-https boot interface of ilo hardware type.

Story: #2008815
Task: #42259
Change-Id: I999f570a0ee6194c3c4625ebaad8275630636e62
'}, {'created': '2021-04-15 09:53:30.000000000', 'message': "Remove boot_method ramdisk parameter for ilo-uefi-https boot interface

When conductor recreates deploy ISO it adds 'boot_method = vmedia' to ramdisk
parameters which works fine with virtual media boot. However for
'ilo-uefi-https' boot interface the IPA fails to find a virtual media device
resulting in heartbeat failure.

Story: #2008815
Task: #42259
Change-Id: I999f570a0ee6194c3c4625ebaad8275630636e62
"}]
commit_message:
Remove boot_method ramdisk parameter for ilo-uefi-https boot interface

When conductor recreates deploy ISO it adds 'boot_method = vmedia' to ramdisk
parameters which works fine with virtual media boot. However for
'ilo-uefi-https' boot interface the IPA fails to find a virtual media device
resulting in heartbeat failure.

Story: #2008815
Task: #42259
Change-Id: I999f570a0ee6194c3c4625ebaad8275630636e62

commit_message:
Disable cinder services on neutron grenade jobs

We don't need it to test cinder in our jobs.
This patch disables Cinder in grenade jobs. If that will be ok
we can do the same for scenario jobs also.

This patch also enables br-ex-tcpdump and br-int-flows
services in the grenade jobs as it was missing there and
may be useful during debugging some failures of those jobs
in the future.

Conflicts:
    zuul.d/grenade.yaml
    .zuul.yaml

Change-Id: If490da1f7e695564a65cabf95f25c72f7639ae19

commit_message:
[only-train] BnR overwrite the json output

The default output for the run_ansible_playbooks is json,
this patch modifies the output to tripleo, so it will be easier for
operators to see the outcome.

The default output from ussuri is tripleo_dense.

Change-Id: Ieb21ff1cd348bff275a14420e3af8a65f401d631

There are also a few other places where we need to use the correct branch.

I have proposed this patch, which we can backport to all branches. https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/kayobe/+/788702 Please review it."}, {'account_id': 28295, 'date': '2021-04-30 19:22:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

commit_message:
Switch Octavia external tasks to 'post deploy'

Octavia needs certain core components to be fully functional and this
isn't the case for some configurations until *after* step 5.

Related-bug: #1914059
Change-Id: I89daa0d195390a672bdb9e4cb416a04a5a88c0bb
(cherry picked from commit 29a5bf31ae0366b944dcc6cc1ea3aaf8881e44c9)
(cherry picked from commit 178018d905d7608696191c78cb02792a7bc91344)

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-04-16 12:29:34.000000000', 'message': 'vmware: Use oslo.vmware's get_moref_value()

With switching the SOAP library backing oslo.vmware [1], the internal
representation of ManagedObjectReference's attributes changes. To be able
to make the switch without interruption, we introduced helper functions
in oslo.vmware. This commit uses one of those - get_moref_value()
- to make the access to the "value" attribute compatible with both
backing libraries.

[1] https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/oslo-specs/specs/victoria/oslo-vmware-soap-library-switch.html

Change-Id: I48841a777aaa2e515c141857099c16483ab619e0
'}, {'created': '2021-04-19 07:31:54.000000000', 'message': 'vmware: Use oslo.vmware's get_moref_value()

commit_message:
vmware: Use oslo.vmware's get_moref_value()

With switching the SOAP library backing oslo.vmware [1], the internal
representation of ManagedObjectReference's attributes changes. To be able
to make the switch without interruption, we introduced helper functions
in oslo.vmware. This commit uses one of those - get_moref_value()
- to make the access to the "value" attribute compatible with both
backing libraries.

Bump oslo.vmware lower-constraint to a version containing the helper
function. We bump one version higher, because we already merged a patch
(I3c769d3499f906b33725171a57313c8ae35b6a1d) that uses the cookiejar
access contained in that version.

[1] https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/oslo-specs/specs/victoria/oslo-vmware-soap-library-switch.html

Change-Id: I48841a777aaa2e515c141857099c16483ab619e0

commit_message:
CI: drop ubuntu-aarch64 job

Rabbitmq requires Erlang 22.3+ while Ubuntu/aarch64 has 22.2 one.

There is no interest in using Ubuntu/aarch64 images so there is no sense
in keeping always failing CI job.

Change-Id: Ia45f01be6724ee60d5993b2ae73648a278fbf6e6

commit_message:
Switch Octavia external tasks to 'post deploy'

Octavia needs certain core components to be fully functional and this
isn't the case for some configurations until *after* step 5.

Related-bug: #1914059

commit_message:
Move projects under meta-config acl (16)

This patch series move openstack/* projects from All-Projects ACL to
meta-config ACL, which is created especially for the Release Managers
group.

commit_message:
Update image_base_image_ref during rebuild.

In different location we assume system_metadata.image_base_image_ref
exists, because it is set during instance creation in method
_populate_instance_for_create

But once instance is rebuild, all system_metadata image property a dropped
and replace by new image property and without setting back
image_base_image_ref.

This change propose to set image_base_image_ref during rebuild.

In specific case of shelve/unshelve in Qcow2 backend, image_base_image_ref is
used to rebase disk image, so we ensure this property is set as instance may
have been rebuild before the fix was apply.

NOTE(lyarwood): An additional change is required within the
ShelvePolicyTestV21 test on stable/ussuri to avoid the system_metadata
of the fake instance being lazy loaded during the test.

Related-Bug: #1732428
Closes-Bug: #1893618
Change-Id: Ia3031ea1f7db8b398f02d2080ca603ded8970200
(cherry picked from commit fe52b6c25bebdd1b459c7a59fbb8d9f6de200c9d)

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-04-09 11:32:47.000000000', 'message': "Rebase qcow2 images when unshelving an instance

During unshelve, instance is spawn with image created by shelve
and is deleted just after, instance.image_ref still point
to the original instance build image.

In qcow2 environment, this is an issue because instance backing file
don't match anymore instance.image_ref and during live-migration/resize,
target host will fetch image corresponding to instance.image_ref
involving instance corruption.

This change fetches original image and rebase instance disk on it.
This avoid image_ref mismatch and bring back storage benefit to keep common
image in cache.

If original image is no more available in glance, backing file is merged into
disk(flatten), ensuring instance integrity during next live-migration/resize
operation.

Change-Id: I1a33fadf0b7439cf06c06cba2bc06df6cef0945b
Closes-Bug: #1732428
(cherry picked from commit 8953a689467f8c3e996086392251de67953a45ba)

commit_message:
Rebase qcow2 images when unshelving an instance

During unshelve, instance is spawn with image created by shelve
and is deleted just after, instance.image_ref still point
to the original instance build image.

In qcow2 environment, this is an issue because instance backing file
don't match anymore instance.image_ref and during live-migration/resize,
target host will fetch image corresponding to instance.image_ref
involving instance corruption.

This change fetches original image and rebase instance disk on it.
This avoid image_ref mismatch and bring back storage benefit to keep common
image in cache.

If original image is no more available in glance, backing file is merged into
disk(flatten), ensuring instance integrity during next live-migration/resize
operation.

Change-Id: I1a33fadf0b7439cf06c06cba2bc06df6cef0945b
Closes-Bug: #1732428
(cherry picked from commit 8953a689467f8c3e996086392251de67953a45ba)

commit_message:
Remove support for openstack releases older than T

This change bumps each openstack chart version up to the next
greatest minor version of 0.2.0, signifying that openstack-helm
will no longer support older, EOL releases for each chart.

Change-Id: I7ce80c7bdc779c1de4472079f18102f506bfbb90

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-02-25 12:55:03.000000000', 'message': "sharder: stall cleaving at shard range gaps

Previously the sharder cleaving process would skip over gaps in shard
ranges. Gaps are not normally expected, but could occur if, for
example, multiple inconsistent decisions are made to configure shards
for shrinking, resulting in a shrinking shard having insufficient
acceptor shard to cover its namespace. In these circumstances the
shrinking shard's cleaving process should stall when it encounters a
gap in the acceptors. This is achieved by always checking that the
lower bound of the next shard range to cleave is less than or equal to
the current cleaving cursor. Cleaving will resume when a suitable
acceptor becomes available to cover the namespace gap.

Change-Id: I1046a5cf809d2a905ede5e1f285939c91843074d
"}, {'created': '2021-03-15 17:25:00.000000000', 'message': "sharder: stall cleaving at shard range gaps

commit_message:
sharder: stall cleaving at shard range gaps

Previously the sharder cleaving process would skip over gaps in shard
ranges. Gaps are not normally expected, but could occur if, for
example, multiple inconsistent decisions are made to configure shards
for shrinking, resulting in a shrinking shard having insufficient
acceptor shard to cover its namespace. In these circumstances the
shrinking shard's cleaving process should stall when it encounters a
gap in the acceptors. This is achieved by always checking that the
lower bound of the next shard range to cleave is less than or equal to
the current cleaving cursor. Cleaving will resume when a suitable
acceptor becomes available to cover the namespace gap.

Change-Id: I1046a5cf809d2a905ede5e1f285939c91843074d

commit_message:
Send additional info to support CMR

Send application name and local unit name when talking to ceph.
This ensures that the response from ceph can be spotted by the
unit making the request.

This is already being done in the classic charms *1

*1 https://review.opendev.org/q/topic:%22bug%252F1780712%22+(status:open%20OR%20status:merged)

Change-Id: I0eb96ab8b1048bf209ffb011dd585af956ab779a
Closes-Bug: #1926667

subject: Backup&Restore Snapshots RFE
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 7353, 'name': 'Kevin Carter', 'email': 'kevin@cloudnull.com', 'username': 'cloudnull'}, {'_account_id': 14985, 'name': 'Alex Schultz', 'email': 'aschultz@next-development.com', 'username': 'mwhahaha'}, {'_account_id': 17823, 'name': 'Michele Baldessari', 'email': 'michele@redhat.com', 'username': 'mbaldessari'}, {'_account_id': 20778, 'name': 'Damien Ciabrini', 'email': 'dciabrin@redhat.com', 'username': 'dciabrin'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 22954, 'name': 'Juan Badia Payno', 'email': 'jbadiapa@redhat.com', 'username': 'jbadiapa'}, {'_account_id': 23181, 'name': 'RDO Third Party CI', 'email': 'dmsimard+rdothirdparty@redhat.com', 'username': 'rdothirdparty', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 32728, 'name': 'Juan Pablo Lopez', 'email': 'jlopezgu@redhat.com', 'username': 'jplopezgu'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 32968, 'date': '2021-04-15 09:35:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 32968, 'date': '2021-04-15 09:36:25.000000000', 'content': 'Set Work In Progress'}, {'account_id': 32968, 'date': '2021-04-15 09:37:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

This change is ready for review.'}, {'account_id': 32968, 'date': '2021-04-15 09:47:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 20778, 'date': '2021-04-20 07:52:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

-1 just so that we start the discussion.
A couple of things come to mind in doing a sequential backup of _all_ nodes:

1. when you do a backup on a stopped controller, the other nodes keep accepting traffic, thus the DB keeps being updated and the nodes slowly drift apart. So chances are that once the third backup gets performed, the first two backup will become useless because they will be so behind that any restore will trigger a SST (a full resync) from the 3rd backup.

2. the restore procedure is the tricky one. Granted, that is not part of this review but I was wondering if there's a solid plan for that already? I.e: do you plan to copy the freshest backup on all nodes and wait avoid a full synchro via SST? Do you plan to restore all three backups and let pacemaker rebootstrap the cluster and wait until galera performs SST on two DB out of the three?

Maybe if there's an external link that I could follow I'd be more at easy with that RFE."}, {'account_id': 32968, 'date': '2021-04-20 09:15:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Hi Damien,

let me explain my and my team's thoughts about the considerations you have:

1. This is true, as the DB keeps being written while the backup on the stopped node is taken, this makes the three nodes drift slightly apart. Obviously, when a restore of the three nodes happens in this situation, one of them (it does not have to be the last one) will overwrite the DB of the other two. I am comfortable with this situation. It does not render the other two backups useless, as the backup is of the whole node, not just the database. The other two backups will not use their own DB copy, but they will use the rest of the backup: Redis, RabbitMQ, Pacemaker, network configurations, disk partitions and a long etcetera. The created backups will allow the user to re-create their overcloud on completely empty machines, and only then, Galera will be able to perform an SST from one node to the other two. The important thing during backup is not to store inconsistent DB state. 

2. The restore procedure could be whatever, it is not limited to one use-case. Having backups of all the nodes, the user could choose to restore whatever fits his use-case. For example, the disk on one of the controllers could fail, render it useless and losing everything. The user could choose just restoring the last backup for that controller on brand new hardware. It is a very quick procedure, letting him have a full controller cluster up&running again in less than 20 minutes. It could be used to restore the three controllers afters a FFU has failed, rendering the controllers unusable. In this case, the three nodes could be restored at the same time. One of the Galeras will SST to the other two, this is fine, as the three copies are good (consistent) and each one of them would be fine to restore. Maybe a disaster struck the user's datacenter, forcing him to create a new cluster out of nothing on new hardware. In this case, the three controllers could also be restored at the same time.

My main concern with this procedure is that it is not really transparent. When the node that holds the vip for the Openstack Services is taken out of the cluster, Pacemaker brings down the vip, rendering the services unusable for the 5-7 seconds that it takes to assign the vip to one of the other two nodes. For the moment, it seems to be acceptable and far better than what we have now, in which the whole overcloud is taken down from the duration of the backup, but do you have an idea on how to perform this action without that small downtime?"}, {'account_id': 20778, 'date': '2021-04-26 14:45:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

Thanks for explaining why 1. still makes sense and 2 is in fact a slightly different concern, it's much clearer now.

I think regarding 3. we may have a mid-term improvement like what we currently do when we run a minor updated in the control plane [1]. To avoid potentially long service disruption, for forcibly move the VIP away from the host that is being updated, just before stopping the cluster. So HAProxy rebalances the traffic very quickly, causing very minimal service disruption if any.

Longer-term, we might think of trigger a database backup with the garbd client. It can freeze one donor node and to get a consistent database copy out of it. But it requires some additional knowledge of the SST method in use and some other complications. Plus the fact that you would probably not be able to get a consistent backup of the entire node. So the mid-term solution is probably the best.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/master/deployment/pacemaker/pacemaker-baremetal-puppet.yaml#L342"}, {'account_id': 32968, 'date': '2021-04-27 09:32:12.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2021-04-30 13:44:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2021-04-30 13:47:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2021-04-15 09:35:50.000000000', 'message': 'Backup&Restore Snapshots RFE

The backup&restore process on the controller needs to be done with
the controller stopped. If that condition is not met, we risk
introducing race conditions that could create unrestorable
non-consistent backups. Currently, the B&R process stops the three
controllers to perform a backup, leaving the cloud unmanageable
during the duration of the backup, which can take several minutes.

This change introduces the capability of doing "serial" backups.
Managing Pacemaker lets us take a node out of the controller
Pacemaker cluster, take a backup from it and introduce it again
on the cluster. While that backup is being done, the other two
nodes of the controller cluster continue to be available to
manage the cloud.

Bugzilla: #1877798
Change-Id: I77c4e6accc205cbc962c663babe1018b51d8d266

commit_message:
Backup&Restore Snapshots RFE

The backup&restore process on the controller needs to be done with
the controller stopped. If that condition is not met, we risk
introducing race conditions that could create unrestorable
non-consistent backups. Currently, the B&R process stops the three
controllers to perform a backup, leaving the cloud unmanageable
during the duration of the backup, which can take several minutes.

This change introduces the capability of doing "serial" backups.
Managing Pacemaker lets us take a node out of the controller
Pacemaker cluster, take a backup from it and introduce it again
on the cluster. While that backup is being done, the other two
nodes of the controller cluster continue to be available to
manage the cloud.

Bugzilla: #1877798
Change-Id: I77c4e6accc205cbc962c663babe1018b51d8d266

Regarding the lightweight:

Currently, there is nothing testing the b&r module. If there is a need we can submit another patch to test it with ubi8 for the tests that are not using it.

commit_message:
Added back the backup-and-restore molecule to the gate

The purpose here is to decouple the patches [1] which fixes
the ansible role and this one which adds the molecule test to the gate.

commit_message:
Validation should use the public endpoint

It was erroneous to use the admin endpoint as it's not accessible from
the undercloud anymore.

Related: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1921114
Change-Id: I2cf2280e4a4599f60c0cce550358f9cf3a20f802
(cherry picked from commit 7e5f0acbe2ed630e3a251c2db74a88833a9fa07f)

commit_message:
Exposing default variables in playbook

This will aloow openstack tripleo-validator run subcommand to override them
and they will be displayed in the show subcommand.

Change-Id: I6901792427ce3045841a31f8cc230c2f909a848f
(cherry picked from commit d9f9f4ecc07e99b84388d2dcf38a47ced46722ca)

subject: Add logic to execute validation groups in updates/upgrades.
messages: [{'account_id': 11090, 'date': '2021-04-29 10:34:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 26343, 'date': '2021-04-30 13:28:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2021-04-29 10:34:54.000000000', 'message': "Add logic to execute validation groups in updates/upgrades.

This commit reshapes the existing updates logic to allow running validations
groups in a more generic way. Including a task file in which the following
is executed:
- Execute the group being passed validation_group if it's included in
  the validation_allowed_groups.
- Log the output into a log file.
- Retrieve the validations results and fail if there is any validation
  failed.
- Log all the tasks executed in each failed validation.

At the same time, this patch invokes the pre-upgrade validation group for
FFU, both before starting with the upgrade (which uses mistral to trigger
the validation in OSP13 [0]) and before starting with the overcloud upgrade
(which uses the new validations framework).

[0] - https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-us/red_hat_openstack_platform/16.1/html/framework_for_upgrades_13_to_16.1/planning-and-preparation-for-an-in-place-openstack-platform-upgrade#validating-red-hat-openstack-platform-oldvernum-before-the-upgrade

Change-Id: I4c70a209283051b3e405bb24e03f555cf3802d94
(cherry picked from commit c945f00f97453018d1b5e531c981dad41fb2a21a)
"}]
commit_message:
Add logic to execute validation groups in updates/upgrades.

This commit reshapes the existing updates logic to allow running validations
groups in a more generic way. Including a task file in which the following
is executed:
- Execute the group being passed validation_group if it's included in
  the validation_allowed_groups.
- Log the output into a log file.
- Retrieve the validations results and fail if there is any validation
  failed.
- Log all the tasks executed in each failed validation.

At the same time, this patch invokes the pre-upgrade validation group for
FFU, both before starting with the upgrade (which uses mistral to trigger
the validation in OSP13 [0]) and before starting with the overcloud upgrade
(which uses the new validations framework).

[0] - https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-us/red_hat_openstack_platform/16.1/html/framework_for_upgrades_13_to_16.1/planning-and-preparation-for-an-in-place-openstack-platform-upgrade#validating-red-hat-openstack-platform-oldvernum-before-the-upgrade

Change-Id: I4c70a209283051b3e405bb24e03f555cf3802d94
(cherry picked from commit c945f00f97453018d1b5e531c981dad41fb2a21a)

commit_message:
nova: Default to the unversioned q35 machine type on x86_64

This change updates the NovaHWMachineType parameter to now default to the
unversioned q35 machine type for x86_64 instances within a deployment.

A simple environment file is also included to pin NovaHWMachineType to
the previous versioned defaults during an upgrade to this release. Once
upgraded operators can then use the following flow to record the machine
type of existing instances allowing the default to eventually be
changed:

https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/admin/hw-machine-type.html

This change depends on Ieb21fd8f3e895ea7611882f1e92f398efe2e77fa to
ensure that the standalone role picks up this new default in CI.

It also depends on Ia3f839a3c5e4e4b59898c11561fe7ef7126bba5f to ensure
that all jobs use cirros 0.5.2 that includes the achi module now
required when using q35 based instances.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-quickstart-extras/+/785575

Finally, it also depends on I0e068043d8267ab91535413d950a3e154c2234f7
from Nova that is attempting to workaround a known QEMU issue that
appears more prevalent when using this newer machine type.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/785682

Change-Id: I9f60a73577ae7cd712e2a8285abc0c0788906112

[{'created': '2021-03-25 09:30:04.000000000', 'message': 'HA: fix race when moving VIP during minor update

During a minor update of a controller node, we list the
VIP hosted on the node and we force them to move away
with a pcs command.

The way we call the pcs command is racy, so change the
action to make sure the VIP move is performed only if
the VIP is still hosted on the node when we run the action.

Change-Id: Id379f4fe1668d01fdd5f91b46e2f75d7cdb577ae
Closes-Bug: #1921351
(cherry picked from commit 3da1e7661036a73c9f222bcdcc489912502d23cb)
'}]
commit_message:
HA: fix race when moving VIP during minor update

During a minor update of a controller node, we list the
VIP hosted on the node and we force them to move away
with a pcs command.

The way we call the pcs command is racy, so change the
action to make sure the VIP move is performed only if
the VIP is still hosted on the node when we run the action.

Change-Id: Id379f4fe1668d01fdd5f91b46e2f75d7cdb577ae
Closes-Bug: #1921351
(cherry picked from commit 3da1e7661036a73c9f222bcdcc489912502d23cb)

commit_message:
[ffwd] Allow users to replace environment files

A new option allows user to replace the content of specific
environment files which are listed in the "overcloud deploy"
bash script which is parsed and used here.

This is useful when the content of a file is known to
have changed between the source and destination release.
The feature is implemented for FFWD only right now,
but it could be used for any kind of upgrade/update process.

Change-Id: I027770e0ac8c73896d2b57218da3a5063b9707fd

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-04-29 18:49:29.000000000', 'message': "Fix async race updating nova configs

The configure_neutron_nova function updates nova configs. While that is
still running we separately update nova configs in stack.sh. This can
result in unexpected configs (that don't work). Fix this by waiting for
configure_neutron_nova to complete its work before we do nova config
updates directly in stack.sh.

For specifics we say that:

  [neutron]
  project_domain_name = Default

was missing from both nova.conf and nova-cpu.conf and instances could
not be created because keystone complained about not finding domain in
project. The strong suspicion here is that on some systems
configure_neutron_nova would write out project_domain_name while the
stack.sh inisets were running resulting in stack.sh overwriting the
project_domain_name content.

Change-Id: I0961d882d555a21233c6b4fbfc077cfe33b88499
"}, {'created': '2021-04-29 18:55:46.000000000', 'message': "Fix async race updating nova configs

The configure_neutron_nova function updates nova configs. While that is
still running we separately update nova configs in stack.sh. This can
result in unexpected configs (that don't work). Fix this by waiting for
configure_neutron_nova to complete its work before we do nova config
updates directly in stack.sh.

For specifics we say that:

  [neutron]
  project_domain_name = Default

was missing from both nova.conf and nova-cpu.conf and instances could
not be created because keystone complained about not finding domain in
project. The strong suspicion here is that on some systems
configure_neutron_nova would write out project_domain_name while the
stack.sh inisets were running resulting in stack.sh overwriting the
project_domain_name content.

One theory is that disabling swift makes this problem more likely as
there is swift work in the middle of the async period. This is supported
by the fact that our job that hits this problem does indeed disable
swift.

Change-Id: I0961d882d555a21233c6b4fbfc077cfe33b88499
"}]
commit_message:
Fix async race updating nova configs

The configure_neutron_nova function updates nova configs. While that is
still running we separately update nova configs in stack.sh. This can
result in unexpected configs (that don't work). Fix this by waiting for
configure_neutron_nova to complete its work before we do nova config
updates directly in stack.sh.

For specifics we say that:

  [neutron]
  project_domain_name = Default

was missing from both nova.conf and nova-cpu.conf and instances could
not be created because keystone complained about not finding domain in
project. The strong suspicion here is that on some systems
configure_neutron_nova would write out project_domain_name while the
stack.sh inisets were running resulting in stack.sh overwriting the
project_domain_name content.

One theory is that disabling swift makes this problem more likely as
there is swift work in the middle of the async period. This is supported
by the fact that our job that hits this problem does indeed disable
swift.

Change-Id: I0961d882d555a21233c6b4fbfc077cfe33b88499

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-04-30 01:59:21.000000000', 'message': "setup.cfg: Replace dashes with underscores

Setuptools v54.1.0 introduces a warning that the use of dash-separated
options in 'setup.cfg' will not be supported in a future version [1].
Get ahead of the issue by replacing the dashes with underscores. Without
this, we see 'UserWarning' messages like the following on new enough
versions of setuptools:

  UserWarning: Usage of dash-separated 'description-file' will not be
  supported in future versions. Please use the underscore name
  'description_file' instead

[1] https://github.com/pypa/setuptools/commit/a2e9ae4cb

Change-Id: I600e640d54fc4750304274e9de24b0a8ab05ea82
"}]
commit_message:
setup.cfg: Replace dashes with underscores

Setuptools v54.1.0 introduces a warning that the use of dash-separated
options in 'setup.cfg' will not be supported in a future version [1].
Get ahead of the issue by replacing the dashes with underscores. Without
this, we see 'UserWarning' messages like the following on new enough
versions of setuptools:

  UserWarning: Usage of dash-separated 'description-file' will not be
  supported in future versions. Please use the underscore name
  'description_file' instead

[1] https://github.com/pypa/setuptools/commit/a2e9ae4cb

Change-Id: I600e640d54fc4750304274e9de24b0a8ab05ea82

Tests for validation.py module and helper classes

Tests for Validation class

Covers most of the methods used by parser, including
the output formatting and argument processing.

Closes-bug: #1922726

commit_message:
Keystone httpd stop listening on ports

When running under httpd, keystone would listen on both ports
:5000 and :35357 and also on :80/identity and :80/identity_v2_admin,
and the catalog was configured to have :80/identity and
:80/identity_admin.

With this change, keystone no longer listens on :5000 and :35357,
only :80/identity and :80/identity_admin.

Change-Id: I3093de7a3410103697236964ca47d856f5193735

commit_message:
Fix python2 compatible ipa creations

Old default versions of setuptools may have issues parsinq requirements.
To keep compatibility with Python 2.x we need to upgrade setuptools in
virtualenvs still using that version.

Change-Id: I61b77ceb6c58b5db451ccbbdfec9d92b4fa5bc89

commit_message:
network: Remove unused 'affect_auto_assigned' parameter

amotoki called this out as unused some time ago. Removing it allows us
to simplify some of the functions here, including removing the unused
'release_floating_ip' and naming 'disassociate_and_release_floating_ip'
as 'release_floating_ip' instead.

Change-Id: I89eb89738852acfa35b6e928804c569a2b45d3dc
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>

subject: Use py3 as the default runtime for tox
messages:
[{'account_id': 30384, 'date': '2021-04-20 06:57:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2021-04-26 11:54:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Hello,

Duplicated with https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/releases/+/787010 .

I prefer to stick to a specific version of python in this repo, by example py38.'}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2021-04-26 15:49:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2021-04-30 11:44:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

I think it makes more sense to use py3 than using a specific version that will change over time. We really don't care that much about what specific version is used, so better to keep it flexible."}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2021-04-30 13:49:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

Agree'}]

this at each new cycle.

commit_message:
doc: Add missing bridge-utils in automated.rst

Without bridge-utils breth1 can't be started:
ifup: parsing file /etc/network/interfaces.d/ifcfg-breth1
ifup: parsing file /etc/network/interfaces.d/ifcfg-eth1

ifup: configuring interface breth1=breth1 (inet)
/bin/run-parts --exit-on-error --verbose /etc/network/if-pre-up.d
run-parts: executing /etc/network/if-pre-up.d/ethtool
/sbin/ip addr add 192.168.33.3/255.255.255.0 broadcast 192.168.33.255 	  dev breth1 label breth1
Cannot find device "breth1"
ifup: failed to bring up breth1

Change-Id: Iae8f3e2d7268fa3001bda314ef982aac9c6d85a3

subject: Fix notification method type DB schema migration
revisions:
[{'created': '2021-04-30 13:12:03.000000000', 'message': 'Fix notification method type DB schema migration

The Stein release does away with the concept of built in notifications,
in favour of treating all notification types equally.

This patch fixes an issue with the DB schema migration associated
with this change, which will fail if any notifications using
built-in notification types are configured at the time of the upgrade.

Story: 2006984
Task: 37746
Change-Id: I2e3f08edf1ab6aec526ad93d04effb91ddca600a
(cherry picked from commit 712f693a72936e102c58a29344aee37e50f57cab)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix notification method type DB schema migration

The Stein release does away with the concept of built in notifications,
in favour of treating all notification types equally.

This patch fixes an issue with the DB schema migration associated
with this change, which will fail if any notifications using
built-in notification types are configured at the time of the upgrade.

Story: 2006984
Task: 37746
Change-Id: I2e3f08edf1ab6aec526ad93d04effb91ddca600a
(cherry picked from commit 712f693a72936e102c58a29344aee37e50f57cab)

[{'created': '2021-04-12 20:24:03.000000000', 'message': "Lazy-load node details from the DB

In order to reduce the load on the database backend, only lazy-load
a node's ports, portgroups, volume_connectors, and volume_targets.
With the power-sync as the main user, this change should reduce the
number of DB operations by two thirds roughly.

Change-Id: Id9a9a53156f7fd866d93569347a81e27c6f0673c
(cherry picked from commit 82cab603bbb21d81769cdc4f50d4fa445d026e5c)
"}]
commit_message:
Lazy-load node details from the DB

In order to reduce the load on the database backend, only lazy-load
a node's ports, portgroups, volume_connectors, and volume_targets.
With the power-sync as the main user, this change should reduce the
number of DB operations by two thirds roughly.

Change-Id: Id9a9a53156f7fd866d93569347a81e27c6f0673c
(cherry picked from commit 82cab603bbb21d81769cdc4f50d4fa445d026e5c)

commit_message:
Make Python Interpreter option for Ansible Validation Run

This patch adds the --python-interpreter argument to the ValidatorRun
subcommand and allows the user to specify their own python interpreter.

Note: This argument was only added in Train by [1] some months ago and
this patch adds it in previous branches.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/python-tripleoclient/commit/8b336981a801857205581029a7668ee0112f8ea5

Authored-By: Mathieu Bultel <mbultel@redhat.com>
Signed-off-by: Gael Chamoulaud (Strider) <gchamoul@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Ieeb0e15533de0eb6fc7ba099cd381182bdb7bc68
(cherry picked from commit 15538634b1ca30639205bbec84ae7b93f501cd44)
(cherry picked from commit 2c23e9fa02f95ac006ab7a3026f872fdee979cdf)

commit_message:
Make Python Interpreter option for Ansible Validation Run

This patch adds the --python-interpreter argument to the ValidatorRun
subcommand and allows the user to specify their own python interpreter.

Note: This argument was only added in Train by [1] some months ago and
this patch adds it in previous branches.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/python-tripleoclient/commit/8b336981a801857205581029a7668ee0112f8ea5

Authored-By: Mathieu Bultel <mbultel@redhat.com>
Signed-off-by: Gael Chamoulaud (Strider) <gchamoul@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Ieeb0e15533de0eb6fc7ba099cd381182bdb7bc68

commit_message:
Make Python Interpreter option for Ansible Validation Run

This patch adds the --python-interpreter argument to the ValidatorRun
subcommand and allows the user to specify their own python interpreter.

Note: This argument was only added in Train by [1] some months ago and
this patch adds it in previous branches.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/python-tripleoclient/commit/8b336981a801857205581029a7668ee0112f8ea5

Authored-By: Mathieu Bultel <mbultel@redhat.com>
Signed-off-by: Gael Chamoulaud (Strider) <gchamoul@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Ieeb0e15533de0eb6fc7ba099cd381182bdb7bc68
(cherry picked from commit 15538634b1ca30639205bbec84ae7b93f501cd44)

(2 comments)

if this is working for you as is then let's merge but mostly wondering why it is failing/timing out (in what cases and why now?)"}, {'account_id': 6683, 'date': '2021-04-01 08:45:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

This is not the correct command causing issue.
It is the following ones which involve repoquery - those listing 'all possibly available packages' ones.

I've added to logs to gitlab (verbose is too detailed/big for pastebins).
In https://gitlab.com/queria/pastebin/-/raw/master/artcl-repoquery/artcl.log there is non-verbose output with list of tasks, there can already be seen that whole log collection took 50 minutes.

This 50 minutes is too much for log collection, our current limit is ~30 minutes (and thats considered extreme, practical goal is ~10 minutes).

Verbose log (2.7MB) is at https://gitlab.com/queria/pastebin/-/raw/master/artcl-repoquery/artcl_verbose.log from there:

  sed -nr 's/.*delta": "(.*)",/\1/p'  artcl-repoquery/artcl_verbose.log| sort -h | tail -n5
  0:03:54.487695
  0:03:57.211378
  0:22:39.874413
  0:22:40.927102
  0:24:38.510121

Shows that there are three very slow steps taking >20 minutes - that is the 'for ... dnf repolist; do repoquery ...; done' tasks when run on controller nodes. (the other 3-4 minute tasks is the same on non-controller nodes [so same task/command still slowest there])

This timeout was suggested as easiest hotfix/protection.
I do not think we need this list-all-possible packages, so timeout seems ok (explicit skip maybe better?) ... in any case i wonder if there is better/faster way how to obtain these information, ideally without having to talk with repository servers at all (just dump local information as the nodes under test know it).
I've tried using --cacheonly for both dnf repolist and dnf repoquery (replaced the non explicit repoquery call) ... with not much big change, this for loop still took bit over 5 minutes in my test machine (and cacheonly cut down only ~20-30 seconds).'}, {'account_id': 6683, 'date': '2021-04-01 08:49:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 24162, 'date': '2021-04-01 10:18:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1
> 
> This is not the correct command causing issue.
> It is the following ones which involve repoquery - those listing 'all possibly available packages' ones.
> 
> I've added to logs to gitlab (verbose is too detailed/big for pastebins).
> In https://gitlab.com/queria/pastebin/-/raw/master/artcl-repoquery/artcl.log there is non-verbose output with list of tasks, there can already be seen that whole log collection took 50 minutes.
> 
> This 50 minutes is too much for log collection, our current limit is ~30 minutes (and thats considered extreme, practical goal is ~10 minutes).
> 
> Verbose log (2.7MB) is at https://gitlab.com/queria/pastebin/-/raw/master/artcl-repoquery/artcl_verbose.log from there:
> 
>   sed -nr 's/.*delta": "(.*)",/\1/p'  artcl-repoquery/artcl_verbose.log| sort -h | tail -n5
>   0:03:54.487695
>   0:03:57.211378
>   0:22:39.874413
>   0:22:40.927102
>   0:24:38.510121
> 
> Shows that there are three very slow steps taking >20 minutes - that is the 'for ... dnf repolist; do repoquery ...; done' tasks when run on controller nodes. (the other 3-4 minute tasks is the same on non-controller nodes [so same task/command still slowest there])
> 
> This timeout was suggested as easiest hotfix/protection.
> I do not think we need this list-all-possible packages, so timeout seems ok (explicit skip maybe better?) ... in any case i wonder if there is better/faster way how to obtain these information, ideally without having to talk with repository servers at all (just dump local information as the nodes under test know it).
> I've tried using --cacheonly for both dnf repolist and dnf repoquery (replaced the non explicit repoquery call) ... with not much big change, this for loop still took bit over 5 minutes in my test machine (and cacheonly cut down only ~20-30 seconds).

My personal take on this is that we should never call remote servers during collection. If something failed we need info not about what is on the remotes but about what happened locally.

Still, I will ask others to comment on this.'}, {'account_id': 6683, 'date': '2021-04-01 11:16:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

So, i'm aware they are not exactly same, question is if it wouldn't be enough here to use just single call?:

  dnf --cacheonly list --all # (or --available, though --all should make no time diff while having more complete list)
  # ... alternativelly if repoquery has better format
  dnf --cacheonly repoquery --all

seems both are lot faster then the loop and repeated calls, but i do not know what the original code was there for, why such information is needed, so this may not be good enough"}, {'account_id': 10969, 'date': '2021-04-01 11:58:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

I think Pavels comments should be addressed'}, {'account_id': 22873, 'date': '2021-04-15 13:59:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

commit_message:
Add 2 minute timeout for repoquery

We encountered an issue when repoquery took several minutes
which has lead to timeouts and unfinished log collections.
To avoid that this commit adds a timeout which is basically
a fail-safe from collect_logs point of view.

The patch replaces for loop for record_available_packages command
by a single command.

Change-Id: Ie3007414aac14db47696fca62b07e1efa4e1de16

commit_message:
Adding tests for sova queries

As the part of check job sova will collect logs
from sample logs and make sure the regexes are valid.
This patch adds a task which checks if sova indeed finds a match for all the regexes defined in queries from the uploaded sample log.
To pass this task there must be an entry corresponding to every item
in queries.yml in errors-testing.err file.

Change-Id: Ie5faebd1f35efc1dc32998dacf5deefdbf6dba94

We have stable/wallaby released so we should add

commit_message:
Add stable/wallaby jobs on master gate

We have stable/wallaby released so we should add
their job on master gate to keep branchless tempest
plugins compatible to stable branch.

This also removes the stable/stein job as that is in EM
state now.

Ref: Tempest plugins guide for stable branch testing:
- https://docs.openstack.org/tempest/latest/stable_branch_testing_policy.html

Change-Id: Icc37ad3818d40f17b51827f8b0d19ca0c7c5bade

commit_message:

"rabbitmqctl status" changed output and check_rabbtimq_file_descriptors.sh
stop to work. This is fixing the issue.

Tested on rabbitmq 3.8.3 Openstack Victoria.

Story: 2008299

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-04-13 13:08:28.000000000', 'message': "Baremetal deploy - user playbook interface

Extend the baremetal deploymend schema with per-role
'ansible_playbooks'. The user can provide a list of
playbooks and extra_vars to include when executing
the playbook. By setting 'pre_network' to 'true' the
playbook will be applied prior to configuring the
network with os-net-config.

Implements: blueprint network-data-v2-ports
Change-Id: I188ee7b47a5dd50ba485b1e8f921f0c13dd34806
"}]
commit_message:
Baremetal deploy - user playbook interface

Extend the baremetal deploymend schema with per-role
'ansible_playbooks'. The user can provide a list of
playbooks and extra_vars to include when executing
the playbook. By setting 'pre_network' to 'true' the
playbook will be applied prior to configuring the
network with os-net-config.

Implements: blueprint network-data-v2-ports
Change-Id: I188ee7b47a5dd50ba485b1e8f921f0c13dd34806

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-04-29 08:22:45.000000000', 'message': 'Make sure the container configuration is refreshed during update.

Following the refactor from Idf004f7a13544dfc1a8a6da033debd1a4f8b96e7
the operations needed to get the container configuration where removed
from the step1 file.

We need to re-include them explicitly during update so that new
changes get taken into account.

In the deployment we have this sequence (keeping only those common
with update):
 - step-0
 - host-prep-task
 - common container setup
 - common deploy steps tasks 1-5

We mimic this sequence in update by placing common container setup
before the common deploy steps tasks 1-5.

Change-Id: I5df88cf9d84f5fecb50b0c602b7923027d5f12b0
Closes-Bug: 1926281
'}]
commit_message:
Make sure the container configuration is refreshed during update.

Following the refactor from Idf004f7a13544dfc1a8a6da033debd1a4f8b96e7
the operations needed to get the container configuration where removed
from the step1 file.

We need to re-include them explicitly during update so that new
changes get taken into account.

In the deployment we have this sequence (keeping only those common
with update):
 - step-0
 - host-prep-task
 - common container setup
 - common deploy steps tasks 1-5

We mimic this sequence in update by placing common container setup
before the common deploy steps tasks 1-5.

Change-Id: I5df88cf9d84f5fecb50b0c602b7923027d5f12b0
Closes-Bug: 1926281

commit_message:
debian-minimal: bullseye: /updates -> -security

With the release of Debian bullseye and later, security updates are
provided in the bullseye-security suite instead of bullseye/updates.

Change-Id: I63580ec96a53e5e8ef8d105e766d838029727917

commit_message:
[CPCEPH-74] Use ca cert for helm tests

This PS will have s3cmd use a ca cert rather than skipping
certificate verification.

commit_message:
[k8s] Keep master nodes role after reboot

Now k8s master nodes will keep its 'master' node after reboot
which can help magnum-auto-healer for simple node repair and
this will benefit other similar cases.

Story: 2008813
Task: 42249

Change-Id: I0fd43540a443e8205860394340dc20381c180a88

commit_message:
Drop support for SQLite < 3.7

Both Ubuntu 18.04 [1] and CentOS 7 [2] provide sufficiently new versions
of SQLite that make this check unnecessary now.

[1] https://packages.ubuntu.com/bionic/sqlite3
[2] http://mirror.centos.org/centos/7/os/x86_64/Packages/

Change-Id: Iba934ce3e91734289351067d4c7b2d1dc2b3f1ea

commit_message:
Validation should use the public endpoint

It was erroneous to use the admin endpoint as it's not accessible from
the undercloud anymore.

Related: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1921114
Change-Id: I2cf2280e4a4599f60c0cce550358f9cf3a20f802
(cherry picked from commit 7e5f0acbe2ed630e3a251c2db74a88833a9fa07f)

subject: Add victoria/wallaby stable branch jobs on master gate
messages: [{'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2021-04-29 23:44:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10234, 'date': '2021-04-30 05:45:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2021-04-29 23:44:01.000000000', 'message': 'Add victoria/wallaby stable branch jobs on master gate

We have stable/victoria and stable/wallaby released so we
should add their job on master gate to keep branchless
tempest plugins compatible to those branch.

This also removes the stable/stein job as that is in EM
state now.

Ref: Tempest plugins guide for stable branch testing:
- https://docs.openstack.org/tempest/latest/stable_branch_testing_policy.html

Change-Id: Ie50c7345b9b56185213e3cd034a30920591cc572
'}]
commit_message:
Add victoria/wallaby stable branch jobs on master gate

We have stable/victoria and stable/wallaby released so we
should add their job on master gate to keep branchless
tempest plugins compatible to those branch.

This also removes the stable/stein job as that is in EM
state now.

Ref: Tempest plugins guide for stable branch testing:
- https://docs.openstack.org/tempest/latest/stable_branch_testing_policy.html

Change-Id: Ie50c7345b9b56185213e3cd034a30920591cc572

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-02-03 21:54:13.000000000', 'message': 'WIP Fix shrinking making acceptors prematurely active

During sharding a shard range is moved to CLEAVED state when cleaved
from its parent. However, during shrinking an acceptor shard should
not be moved to CLEAVED state when the shrinking shard cleaves to it,
because the shrinking shard is not its parent and does not know if the
acceptor has yet been cleaved from its parent.

The existing attempt to prevent a shrinking shard updating its
acceptor state relied on comparing the acceptor namespace to the
shrinking shard namespace: if the acceptor namespace fully enclosed
the shrinkng shard then it was inferred that shrinking was taking
place. That check is sufficient for normal shrinking of one shard into
an expanding acceptor, but is not sufficient when shrinking in order
to fix overlaps, when a shard might shrink into more than one
acceptor, none of which completely enclose the shrinking shard.

Fortunately it is now possible to infer that a shard is shrinking more
explcitly from its state being either SHRINKING or SHRUNK.

Change-Id: I91110bc747323e757d8b63003ad3d38f915c1f35
'}, {'created': '2021-02-04 19:13:24.000000000', 'message': "Fix shrinking making acceptors prematurely active

During sharding a shard range is moved to CLEAVED state when cleaved
from its parent. However, during shrinking an acceptor shard should
not be moved to CLEAVED state when the shrinking shard cleaves to it,
because the shrinking shard is not the acceptor's parent and does not
know if the acceptor has yet been cleaved from its parent.

The existing attempt to prevent a shrinking shard updating its
acceptor state relied on comparing the acceptor namespace to the
shrinking shard namespace: if the acceptor namespace fully enclosed
the shrinkng shard then it was inferred that shrinking was taking
place. That check is sufficient for normal shrinking of one shard into
an expanding acceptor, but is not sufficient when shrinking in order
to fix overlaps, when a shard might shrink into more than one
acceptor, none of which completely encloses the shrinking shard.

Fortunately, since [1], it is possible to determine that a shard is
shrinking from its own shard range state being either SHRINKING or
SHRUNK.

[1] Related-Change: I9034a5715406b310c7282f1bec9625fe7acd57b6
Change-Id: I91110bc747323e757d8b63003ad3d38f915c1f35
"}, {'created': '2021-02-05 20:14:22.000000000', 'message': "Fix shrinking making acceptors prematurely active

During sharding a shard range is moved to CLEAVED state when cleaved
from its parent. However, during shrinking an acceptor shard should
not be moved to CLEAVED state when the shrinking shard cleaves to it,
because the shrinking shard is not the acceptor's parent and does not
know if the acceptor has yet been cleaved from its parent.

The existing attempt to prevent a shrinking shard updating its
acceptor state relied on comparing the acceptor namespace to the
shrinking shard namespace: if the acceptor namespace fully enclosed
the shrinkng shard then it was inferred that shrinking was taking
place. That check is sufficient for normal shrinking of one shard into
an expanding acceptor, but is not sufficient when shrinking in order
to fix overlaps, when a shard might shrink into more than one
acceptor, none of which completely encloses the shrinking shard.

Fortunately, since [1], it is possible to determine that a shard is
shrinking from its own shard range state being either SHRINKING or
SHRUNK.

It is still advantageous to delete and merge the shrinking shard range
into the acceptor when the acceptor fully encloses the shrinking shard
because that increases the likelihood of the root being updated with
the deleted shard range in a timely manner.

Also, prevent cleaving starting if the acceptor shard ranges do not
start at the lower bound of the shrinking shard namespace.

[1] Related-Change: I9034a5715406b310c7282f1bec9625fe7acd57b6
Change-Id: I91110bc747323e757d8b63003ad3d38f915c1f35
"}, {'created': '2021-02-08 09:19:48.000000000', 'message': "Fix shrinking making acceptors prematurely active

The existing attempt to prevent a shrinking shard updating its

place. That check is sufficient for normal shrinking of one shard into

Fortunately, since [1], it is possible to determine that a shard is

It is still advantageous to delete and merge the shrinking shard range

because that increases the likelihood of the root being updated with

Also, prevent cleaving starting if the acceptor shard ranges do not

from its parent. However, during shrinking an acceptor shard should
not be moved to CLEAVED state when the shrinking shard cleaves to it,
because the shrinking shard is not the acceptor's parent and does not
know if the acceptor has yet been cleaved from its parent.

The existing attempt to prevent a shrinking shard updating its
acceptor state relied on comparing the acceptor namespace to the
shrinking shard namespace: if the acceptor namespace fully enclosed
the shrinkng shard then it was inferred that shrinking was taking
place. That check is sufficient for normal shrinking of one shard into
an expanding acceptor, but is not sufficient when shrinking in order
to fix overlaps, when a shard might shrink into more than one
acceptor, none of which completely encloses the shrinking shard.

Fortunately, since [1], it is possible to determine that a shard is
shrinking from its own shard range state being either SHRINKING or
SHRUNK.

It is still advantageous to delete and merge the shrinking shard range
into the acceptor when the acceptor fully encloses the shrinking shard
because that increases the likelihood of the root being updated with
the deleted shard range in a timely manner.

Also, prevent cleaving starting if the acceptor shard ranges do not
start at the lower bound of the shrinking shard namespace.

[1] Related-Change: I9034a5715406b310c7282f1bec9625fe7acd57b6
Change-Id: I91110bc747323e757d8b63003ad3d38f915c1f35

commit_message:
Fix shrinking making acceptors prematurely active

During sharding a shard range is moved to CLEAVED state when cleaved
from its parent. However, during shrinking an acceptor shard should
not be moved to CLEAVED state when the shrinking shard cleaves to it,
because the shrinking shard is not the acceptor's parent and does not
know if the acceptor has yet been cleaved from its parent.

The existing attempt to prevent a shrinking shard updating its
acceptor state relied on comparing the acceptor namespace to the
shrinking shard namespace: if the acceptor namespace fully enclosed
the shrinkng shard then it was inferred that shrinking was taking
place. That check is sufficient for normal shrinking of one shard into
an expanding acceptor, but is not sufficient when shrinking in order
to fix overlaps, when a shard might shrink into more than one
acceptor, none of which completely encloses the shrinking shard.

Fortunately, since [1], it is possible to determine that a shard is
shrinking from its own shard range state being either SHRINKING or
SHRUNK.

It is still advantageous to delete and merge the shrinking shard range
into the acceptor when the acceptor fully encloses the shrinking shard
because that increases the likelihood of the root being updated with
the deleted shard range in a timely manner.

[1] Related-Change: I9034a5715406b310c7282f1bec9625fe7acd57b6
Change-Id: I91110bc747323e757d8b63003ad3d38f915c1f35

commit_message:
debian-minimal: Set bullseye version

Currently Debian sets /etc/debian_version to "bullseye/sid" and, due
to a series of issues explained in [1] more fully "lsb_release -c" in
the OpenDev environment doesn't return the distribution code name.
Overriding this to the final release version fixes this.

[1] http://lists.opendev.org/pipermail/service-discuss/2021-April/000222.html

Change-Id: I00c1741dac6ad5f2c4bf855a207f17d8985bc763

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-03-16 11:38:41.000000000', 'message': "Sets test env python version to 3.6

Python 3.6 is the oldest still supported by master.
While later versions didn't break any functionality already
present in 3.6 they've added several new features.

https://docs.python.org/3/whatsnew/3.7.html
https://docs.python.org/3/whatsnew/3.8.html

As it may be possible that VF developers employ any one of several
supported python versions, features introduced in Python >3.6
might find their way in the codebase without triggering
stestr run unittests, as they themselves are run within 3.8 environment.

This patch addresses such possibility.

Signed-off-by: Jiri Podivin <jpodivin@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Ia0945a7764b4857ae70b6099aa7441d99631729f
"}, {'created': '2021-04-06 13:45:33.000000000', 'message': "Sets test env python version to 3.6

commit_message:
Sets test env python version to 3.6

Python 3.6 is the oldest still supported by master.
While later versions didn't break any functionality already
present in 3.6 they've added several new features.

https://docs.python.org/3/whatsnew/3.7.html
https://docs.python.org/3/whatsnew/3.8.html

As it may be possible that VF developers employ any one of several
supported python versions, features introduced in Python >3.6
might find their way in the codebase without triggering
stestr run unittests, as they themselves are run within 3.8 environment.

This patch addresses such possibility.

Closes-Bug: #1922726

Signed-off-by: Jiri Podivin <jpodivin@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Ia0945a7764b4857ae70b6099aa7441d99631729f

commit_message:
Collect openstack logs

This will aid debugging of nova 500 errors when doing the trivial boots
of cirros to validate the cloud is functional.

Change-Id: Idd6d406e3a5a6ea5dd046c61c391c8f6147a9168

commit_message:
Fix centos stream set mirror

This intents to fix job dib-functests-bionic-python3-image.
And no CentOS-Stream-centosplus.repo file[1].

[1]: http://rpm.pbone.net/info_idpl_72967298_distro_centosother_com_centos-stream-repos-8-2.el8.noarch.rpm.html

Change-Id: I9d69413f31d0a9d83e992d05d177f683b7361337

commit_message:
Rename image-yaml *-python3* back to *-base*

They used to be named *-base* but were renamed for py2/py3 transition.
This change renames them back to base, and adds symlinks to the old
name until CI jobs can be updated to use the new name.

Change-Id: I30728af8e7cbae049f266b5dac61e185336ce085
